headers.access-control-expose-headers: ETag, Link, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval

issue.title: Focus stuck in Electron applications on raw X session
issue.body:
Hello.

Normally, on a raw X session (i.e. without window managers), a window under the mouse cursor becomes active:
![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4298265/12291256/8f5ecf90-ba29-11e5-852c-8a5ef21c8332.gif)

However, electron applications don't allow other windows to focus on even if the mouse cursor is over the other windows:
![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4298265/12291310/c2ac42ec-ba29-11e5-85e9-f23f826f0738.gif)

I ran this application https://gist.github.com/Terminus-IMRC/aca2b09186e8ab7ae3e3 in the movie above.
And I used Electron v0.36.3 on Linux.

This behavior is inconvenient.
Why is this occurring and could you fix this?

Thanks in advance for your answers.

Regards,
Terminus-IMRC.

comment.body:
No. Chromium has the same problem.
So, is this a Chromium issue?

issue.title: undefined ipcRenderer
issue.body:
Good morning guys, yesterday I updated the version of electron and now I'm having a lot of problems. I got the latest version of electron-prebuilt and electron and this is my problem

```javascript
var ipc = require('electron').ipcRenderer;
console.log(ipc);
```
the console.log print undefined...

I have no idea whats going on...

```javascript
"electron-prebuilt": "^0.36.3"
"electron": "^0.4.1"
```

Thanks

comment.body:
@zcbenz why the documentation haven't got that information? 

Thanks for your help

issue.title: Loading pepper plugins and EME support via CDMs
issue.body:
Is there an aim for Electron to support the loading of generic pepper plugins in the future? I'm asking as I'd like to understand the chances of getting a fork that achieves this (or part of it) merged into master.

Specifically my goal is to support [EMEs](https://w3c.github.io/encrypted-media/) and allow pepper plugin based [CDMs](https://w3c.github.io/encrypted-media/#definitions) load in a `<webview>`.

Trouble is I have a naive understanding of how Electron and Chromium work together. Looking at how the Pepper Flash Player was integrated then generic support appears to be easier. It should require exetending Electrons switches to recognise and proxy `--register-pepper-plugins`, there isn't any code needed to handle plugin versions.

Starting with a build of Chromium 45 I can get encrypted Widevine media playing back by using the  switch `--register-pepper-plugins="widevinecdmadapter.plugin;application/x-ppapi-widevine-cdm"`. This suggests that once versions align (I think it can be done with m44) then it's possible to experiment in Electron.

The above is pretty specific, so I'd be glad to hear about anything I've missed that might trip this up. Or if it sounds like I'm on the right track then any pointers (aside from the Flash implementation) would be valuable.

comment.body: still gettin issue with netflix all plugins included widevine - also present, but netflix return 3003 error  without any description, any suggestions?

issue.title: electron occasionally freezes (from crash) in headless browser testing
issue.body:
i've replaced phantomjs with electron @ v0.35.4 for my headless browser-tests.  it will occasionally crash (about 10% of time), when running an intentionally faulty browser script, to test failure-cases in my testing library.

here's the line where it fails on travis-ci (i have a separate detached process that will kill electron after 60 seconds):
https://travis-ci.org/kaizhu256/node-utility2/jobs/96600773#L728
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/280571/11811467/a44d9834-a370-11e5-8342-a2fec67cc2da.png)

and here is the webpage with intentionally faulty javascript (throws an uncaught error) that will freeze electron
https://hrku01-utility2-beta.herokuapp.com/test/script-only.html?modeTest=consoleLogResult&modeTestCase=testCase_testRun_failure&timeExit=9999999999

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/280571/11811253/772f2184-a36f-11e5-9e0d-a2e39e9c2efe.png)


i create a new BrowserWindow for the testpage, so it has no access to native nodejs features.
here is my headless browser test subroutine:
https://github.com/kaizhu256/node-utility2/blob/702c054f71094e5d37290bd681e6c829ecaffd58/index.js#L110


sorry i can't give more info about the cause of the bug.  i can't open the web inspector with recent releases of electron

P.S. electron @ v0.36.0 is unusable.  it always freezes, when running the error-script.
the 10% failure rate occurs when i enable istanbul-code-coverage on browser-side.
if i run tests without code-coverage, the freeze-failure drops to ~1%

issue.title: electron occasionally freezes (from crash) in headless browser testing
issue.body:
i've replaced phantomjs with electron @ v0.35.4 for my headless browser-tests.  it will occasionally crash (about 10% of time), when running an intentionally faulty browser script, to test failure-cases in my testing library.

here's the line where it fails on travis-ci (i have a separate detached process that will kill electron after 60 seconds):

comment.body: Closing until more information is provided.

issue.title: Is Electron adding "Origin: file://" to my outbound request? If yes how do I prevent this?
issue.body:
The server that I am talking to is refusing to respond because the request from Electron contains a header with "Origin: file://"  I have no control over the target server so the only thing I can address is the client side (hopefully).

Is Electron adding this header?  How do I stop it? Hopefully something can be done because if not then it's not possible to talk to Amazon Web Services from electron which would be problematic.

thanks

issue.title: Is Electron adding "Origin: file://" to my outbound request? If yes how do I prevent this?
issue.body:
The server that I am talking to is refusing to respond because the request from Electron contains a header with "Origin: file://"  I have no control over the target server so the only thing I can address is the client side (hopefully).

Is Electron adding this header?  How do I stop it? Hopefully something can be done because if not then it's not possible to talk to Amazon Web Services from electron which would be problematic.

thanks

comment.body: Closing until more information is provided.

issue.title: libwebp dependency broken
issue.body:
On Arch Linux (and presumably other distros in the near future), libwebp ships `libwebpdemux.so.2` rather than `libwebpdemux.so.1`. This causes electron to fail:

`/usr/lib/electron/electron: error while loading shared libraries: libwebpdemux.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

[[packages/libwebp] - updated to 0.5.0 (note: new soname) - enable libwebpextras library](https://www.mail-archive.com/pld-cvs-commit@lists.pld-linux.org/msg381646.html)
[Arch package](https://www.archlinux.org/packages/extra/x86_64/libwebp/)

issue.title: Hardware acceleration doesn't work in Flash plugin
issue.body:
On Windows (don't know about other OS's) (Tried with many releases of Electron)

When loading a Flash based video player in Electron, it seems to consume more GPU and Memory in the gpu-process and the pappi process respectively compared to Chromium.

I've tried to compare the flags passed to the pappi and gpu-process in chromium in an attempt to make them the most alike possible. So I've came up with those commandLine switches:
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-path', path.join(__dirname, 'plugins', 'pepflashplayer19.dll')); // Used the latest pepperflash player i could find.
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-version', '19.0.0.245');
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-args', 'enable_hw_video_decode=1');
Only the last switch was new for Electron (found it from how Chromium opens it's pappi process)

Just as a sake of comparison, when playing the video in fullscreen in Electron, the gpu-process consumes about 17-18% of my GPU, while on Chromium (and Chrome) the GPU seems to stay around 4%. 

On another note, the pappi process seems to not be able to clean it's memory as nicely as on Chromium, I can't really describe it, but it just seems to get better garbage collected in Chromium as the video plays. 

Regarding the renderer process and the pappi process, they seem to consume also more CPU than in Chromium.

All this using a simple hosted video play to which I win.loadURL to in Electron, and simply open the same URL in Chromium, for the sake of comparison. 

I've been using Process Explorer to find out the GPU usage of the applications.

This ticket is basically to see if anyone has encountered this difference and found a solution to this. Are there maybe other switches that could maybe make Electron consume less GPU ? Or is there a reason this is happening in Electron vs Chromium ?

In my Electron application, I'll have to play some videos for hours at the time and a good memory garbage collection and GPU usage sure would helps considering that it'll often run on Intel CPU+CPU chips. (in my case, 17% of is a breeze for my top of the line video card, but that same 17% would translate to a higher % on CPU+GPU chips.)

Any ideas would be appreciated. Feel free to ask for more details.

issue.title: Hardware acceleration doesn't work in Flash plugin
issue.body:
On Windows (don't know about other OS's) (Tried with many releases of Electron)

When loading a Flash based video player in Electron, it seems to consume more GPU and Memory in the gpu-process and the pappi process respectively compared to Chromium.

I've tried to compare the flags passed to the pappi and gpu-process in chromium in an attempt to make them the most alike possible. So I've came up with those commandLine switches:
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-path', path.join(__dirname, 'plugins', 'pepflashplayer19.dll')); // Used the latest pepperflash player i could find.
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-version', '19.0.0.245');
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('ppapi-flash-args', 'enable_hw_video_decode=1');
Only the last switch was new for Electron (found it from how Chromium opens it's pappi process)

Just as a sake of comparison, when playing the video in fullscreen in Electron, the gpu-process consumes about 17-18% of my GPU, while on Chromium (and Chrome) the GPU seems to stay around 4%. 

On another note, the pappi process seems to not be able to clean it's memory as nicely as on Chromium, I can't really describe it, but it just seems to get better garbage collected in Chromium as the video plays. 

Regarding the renderer process and the pappi process, they seem to consume also more CPU than in Chromium.

All this using a simple hosted video play to which I win.loadURL to in Electron, and simply open the same URL in Chromium, for the sake of comparison. 

I've been using Process Explorer to find out the GPU usage of the applications.

This ticket is basically to see if anyone has encountered this difference and found a solution to this. Are there maybe other switches that could maybe make Electron consume less GPU ? Or is there a reason this is happening in Electron vs Chromium ?

In my Electron application, I'll have to play some videos for hours at the time and a good memory garbage collection and GPU usage sure would helps considering that it'll often run on Intel CPU+CPU chips. (in my case, 17% of is a breeze for my top of the line video card, but that same 17% would translate to a higher % on CPU+GPU chips.)

Any ideas would be appreciated. Feel free to ask for more details.

issue.title: Change dock icon dynamically
issue.body: Will something like `app.dock.setIcon` be possible? Thanks.

comment.body: It should be possible by calling the `[NSApp setApplicationIconImage]` API.

issue.title: Pm2 startup causes electron app to be launched maximized not fullscreened
issue.body:
https://github.com/MassambaDiouf/Electron-FullScreen-HelloWorld

In Ubuntu 14.04 LTS:

When using Pm2 to launch an electron app at startup, the app will be maximized (panel will still be visible) not fullscreened. However if the pm2 process is deleted and relaunched it will then be fullscreened. I believe this is a problem with electron and Ubuntu, a link to a public repository has been added above that replicates the error.

issue.title: Focus stuck in Electron applications on raw X session
issue.body:
Hello.

Normally, on a raw X session (i.e. without window managers), a window under the mouse cursor becomes active:
![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4298265/12291256/8f5ecf90-ba29-11e5-852c-8a5ef21c8332.gif)

However, electron applications don't allow other windows to focus on even if the mouse cursor is over the other windows:
![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4298265/12291310/c2ac42ec-ba29-11e5-85e9-f23f826f0738.gif)

I ran this application https://gist.github.com/Terminus-IMRC/aca2b09186e8ab7ae3e3 in the movie above.
And I used Electron v0.36.3 on Linux.

This behavior is inconvenient.
Why is this occurring and could you fix this?

Thanks in advance for your answers.

Regards,
Terminus-IMRC.

comment.body: Does the Chromium browser work as expected?

issue.title: dialog.showMessageBox: `cancelId` clarification
issue.body:
Sorry for all the issues, doing a bit of research into the APIs :). So, `cancelId` has this description:

>`cancelId` Integer - The value will be returned when user cancels the dialog instead of clicking the buttons of the dialog. By default it is the index of the buttons that have "cancel" or "no" as label, or 0 if there is no such buttons. On OS X and Windows the index of "Cancel" button will always be used as cancelId, not matter whether it is already specified.

If you don't have a `cancel` or `no` button and `0` is used, will the callback be called with `1` if your first button is clicked, `2` if the second is clicked, and so on?

Also, about this bit:

>On OS X and Windows the index of "Cancel" button will always be used as cancelId, not matter whether it is already specified.

What happens if there is no `Cancel` button?

comment.body:
>The callback will be called with button's index when button is clicked, so 0 for 1st button.

So you can't tell if they clicked the button or cancelled then?

>The community is usually a better place for this kind of questions, and the best way is to try it yourself.

Ok thanks, noted. I felt like this was verging on bug territory so I put it here. Like what I'm saying above about not knowing if a button was clicked or if it was cancelled. Thanks

issue.title: dialog.showMessageBox without parameters throws error about buttons
issue.body: The [docs](http://electron.atom.io/docs/v0.36.0/api/dialog/) say the params are optional. Not sure if it's just that the docs are wrong or not.

comment.body: Also, that doesn't explain why `dialog.showMessageBox({buttons: ['hello']})` works but `dialog.showMessageBox(BrowserWindow, {buttons: ['hello']}, function(){});` doesn't.

issue.title: undefined ipcRenderer
issue.body:
Good morning guys, yesterday I updated the version of electron and now I'm having a lot of problems. I got the latest version of electron-prebuilt and electron and this is my problem

```javascript
var ipc = require('electron').ipcRenderer;
console.log(ipc);
```
the console.log print undefined...

I have no idea whats going on...

```javascript
"electron-prebuilt": "^0.36.3"
"electron": "^0.4.1"
```

Thanks

issue.title: undefined ipcRenderer
issue.body:
Good morning guys, yesterday I updated the version of electron and now I'm having a lot of problems. I got the latest version of electron-prebuilt and electron and this is my problem

```javascript
var ipc = require('electron').ipcRenderer;
console.log(ipc);
```
the console.log print undefined...

I have no idea whats going on...

```javascript
"electron-prebuilt": "^0.36.3"
"electron": "^0.4.1"
```

Thanks

comment.body: The npm `electron` module conflicts with electron's built-in module, if you want to use the npm module you have to use `require('ipc-renderer')` instead of `require('electron').ipcRenderer`.

payload.description: Build cross platform desktop apps with web technologies

issue.title: undefined ipcRenderer
issue.body:
Good morning guys, yesterday I updated the version of electron and now I'm having a lot of problems. I got the latest version of electron-prebuilt and electron and this is my problem

```javascript
var ipc = require('electron').ipcRenderer;
console.log(ipc);
```
the console.log print undefined...

I have no idea whats going on...

```javascript
"electron-prebuilt": "^0.36.3"
"electron": "^0.4.1"
```

Thanks

comment.body:
If the snippet you paste is from your package.json, you probably depend on [paradox electron module](https://www.npmjs.com/package/electron) for mistake. This module has nothing to do with electron platform. You only need  electron-prebuilt dependency.

Maybe your problem is due to the fact that you get this module when you `require('electron')` you get paradox module instead of Electron builtin. Try remove it

issue.title: Add a way to force flushing localStorage
issue.body: I am often seeing that the state in localStorage is not flushed to disk when Electron crashes abnormally. It would be nice if Electron could expose API to force a flush to disk of the storage state so that applications can periodically make sure all state is persisted.

comment.body: Amazing, thanks so much!

@zcbenz interesting, it does not seem to be mentioned in their changelog, the last entry I see is the update to V8 46: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#commits-9

Somehow I thought they would keep the major node.js releases in sync with the V8 releases, but now node.js 5 jumped from 45 to 46 to 47.

issue.title: sending keyboard events serially
issue.body:
It appears that `sendInputEvent` (https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/2269) is an asynchronous event. This is causing problems if you'd like to type more than one character into a text box (see https://github.com/segmentio/nightmare/issues/414 for more information).

Is there anyway to execute these events serially or provide a callback or something when the input event has finished?

issue.title: [WIP] Convert from CoffeeScript to JavaScript
issue.body:
This pull request migrates all of the CoffeeScript source files to JavaScript.

:chart_with_upwards_trend: CoffeeScript was great when this project started, but many of the best parts of it are now in ES6 and available out of the box in Electron. See [this blog post](http://blog.atom.io/2016/01/07/latest-v8-chromium-features.html) for some examples.

:coffee: The JavaScript files in this pull request were generated using CoffeeScript `1.10.0`.  A second pass will be made in a follow-up pull request to reformat the JavaScript and draft a new styleguide. This is done to minimally disrupt any open or soon to be opened pull requests that may touch the existing `.coffee` files.

:memo: The comments have been retained by first migrating all the `#` comments to `###` which were then compiled to `/* */` style comments in the JavaScript.

:dart: The goal is to make Electron as approachable as possible and also to have its source code reflect the capabilities of the V8 version being used.

### Changes to be made in subsequent pull requests

  - Cleanup accidental `return` statements
  - Cleanup comment formatting
  - Cleanup variable scoping
  - Remove CoffeeScript helpers like `extend`, `slice`, and `indexOf`
  - Use `let` and `const` appropriately
  - Use arrow (`=>`) functions

comment.body: I'm so happy for this change :smile:

This pull request migrates all of the CoffeeScript source files to JavaScript.

:chart_with_upwards_trend: CoffeeScript was great when this project started, but many of the best parts of it are now in ES6 and available out of the box in Electron. See [this blog post](http://blog.atom.io/2016/01/07/latest-v8-chromium-features.html) for some examples.

:coffee: The JavaScript files in this pull request were generated using CoffeeScript `1.10.0`.  A second pass will be made in a follow-up pull request to reformat the JavaScript and draft a new styleguide. This is done to minimally disrupt any open or soon to be opened pull requests that may touch the existing `.coffee` files.

:memo: The comments have been retained by first migrating all the `#` comments to `###` which were then compiled to `/* */` style comments in the JavaScript.

:dart: The goal is to make Electron as approachable as possible and also to have its source code reflect the capabilities of the V8 version being used.

### Changes to be made in subsequent pull requests

  - Cleanup accidental `return` statements
  - Cleanup comment formatting
  - Cleanup variable scoping
  - Remove CoffeeScript helpers like `extend`, `slice`, and `indexOf`
  - Use `let` and `const` appropriately
  - Use arrow (`=>`) functions

issue.title: [WIP] Convert from CoffeeScript to JavaScript
issue.body:
This pull request migrates all of the CoffeeScript source files to JavaScript.

:chart_with_upwards_trend: CoffeeScript was great when this project started, but many of the best parts of it are now in ES6 and available out of the box in Electron. See [this blog post](http://blog.atom.io/2016/01/07/latest-v8-chromium-features.html) for some examples.

:coffee: The JavaScript files in this pull request were generated using CoffeeScript `1.10.0`.  A second pass will be made in a follow-up pull request to reformat the JavaScript and draft a new styleguide. This is done to minimally disrupt any open or soon to be opened pull requests that may touch the existing `.coffee` files.

:memo: The comments have been retained by first migrating all the `#` comments to `###` which were then compiled to `/* */` style comments in the JavaScript.

:dart: The goal is to make Electron as approachable as possible and also to have its source code reflect the capabilities of the V8 version being used.

### Changes to be made in subsequent pull requests

  - Cleanup accidental `return` statements
  - Cleanup comment formatting
  - Cleanup variable scoping
  - Remove CoffeeScript helpers like `extend`, `slice`, and `indexOf`
  - Use `let` and `const` appropriately
  - Use arrow (`=>`) functions
